result.execSummary:
The defendant Igor Donkovtsev was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting/Failing to Stop/Fleeing, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.04(2t).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Undergo any counseling per agent. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Defendant Igor Donkovtsev in court with attorney Corey Chirafisi.  Sue Mueller with intern Rick S. appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Chirafisi gives agreement.  Count 1 & 2.   Court withholds sentence.

Paperwork handed in court.

Cash bond to apply.
Sentencing hearing at 06-05-2015 01:00 pm

Defendant Igor Donkovtsev in court with attorney Corey Chirafisi.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Atty Chirafisi states parties have joint recommendation for probation but DE needs to become a resident first but asks for 10 days to do sentencing and just do a plea today.  Atty Chirafisi states agreement.  State agrees and doesn't object to sentencing being set over.  State moves to amend Ct 1 to 346.04(2)(t) failure to stop for traffic officer.  Court so orders.  Atty Chirafisi enters NC pleas to count 1 and 2.  DE agrees.  Court questions DE on pleas/accepts/finds guilty.  Sentencing date set out.  Bond continued pending sentencing.

Defendant Igor Donkovtsev in court with attorney Verhoff.   Michael Albrecht appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  State ready to proceed.  Attorney advises court of issues of motion.  Motorcycle and cell phone at issue.  State addresses issue on property still in custody w/ Sheriff's Dept.  Search warrant could also be filed in the future.  Both pieces of property to remain as evidence.  Attorney Verhoff responds.  Court rules to deny the motion to return the cycle and cell phone at this time.   When matter is resolved, property would likely be returned.  Not contraband.  Bond continues.
